title: 114_hr4232
content: The "Ratepayer Fairness Act of 2015" also addresses cross-subsidization of customer-side technology. The "Ratepayer Fairness Act of 2015" addresses cross-subsidization of customer-side technology by amending Section 111(d) of the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act of 1978 to consider the impact of customer-side technology connected to the electricity distribution system. The "Ratepayer Fairness Act of 2015" requires State regulatory authorities and nonregulated electric utilities to consider the impact of customer-side technology on rates, ensuring that any subsidies for such technology primarily benefit its users. The "Ratepayer Fairness Act of 2015" mandates State regulatory authorities and electric utilities to assess the effects of customer-side technology on rates, preventing cost shifts to non-users and avoiding negative impacts on resource utilization, grid reliability, and competitive fairness. The State regulatory authority must disclose any fraudulent customer-side technology marketing practices and evaluate cross-subsidization of customer-side technology at least 90 days before a proceeding. Compliance with the "Ratepayer Fairness Act of 2015" is required. Each State regulatory authority and nonregulated electric utility must begin considering or set a hearing date for the standard established by section 111(d) within 1 year of enactment. Within 2 years, a hearing must be set for each electric utility under State regulatory authority. Compliance with the "Ratepayer Fairness Act of 2015" is mandatory. Each State regulatory authority and nonregulated electric utility must consider the standard set by section 111(d) within 1 year of enactment. Failure to comply will result in amendments to the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act of 1978. Compliance with the "Ratepayer Fairness Act of 2015" is required.
